author: JamesWTruher
body:
Assume that I have written a script which is a paragon of portability. It runs on all the platforms without modification, and is in my PATH. On Windows, I type:
`PS> Hello`
and it executes!

should I be able to do the same on non-windows platforms? Note that I have not typed the actual name of the file on Windows (which is `hello.ps1`), just `hello`.

`#!powershell` does not address this issue, because it doesn't change the name of the script. Are we going to suggest that our users create 2 copies of the same file:
`hello` and `hello.ps1`
one for Windows, another for not?
are we going to require our users to type `hello.ps1` on non-Windows platforms?

I suggest that we support our current behavior on non-Windows platforms, we supply the `.ps1`, and use the same disambiguation logic that we do for  `.cmd`, `.exe`, etc, which an additional ` ` which is no extension. This way if files (on non-windows)

```
hello
hello.ps1
```

we would execute `hello`.  _similar to what we would do if we found_ `hello.exe` _on windows_
If we find only `hello.ps1`, and the user types `hello`, we run it and not require the user to type the actual filename
title: Should non-windows system users be required to include the extension when executing scripts?
